intro: Gilia ochroleuca subsp. ochroleuca, commonly known as the yellow gilia, is a flowering plant native to the western United States. It is a member of the Malvaceae family and is characterized by its showy, yellow-orange flowers that bloom in summer. The plant typically grows in dry, open habitats such as grasslands and rocky slopes. It has hairy, slender stems and lance-shaped leaves that are often covered in fine pubescence. The flowers are arranged in racemes and attract various pollinators, including bees and butterflies.
